column1: Implement Intkey -> PostGRES State Delta Subscription Example
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Implement a state delta subscriber that listens for Intkey state deltas, and inserts them into a PostGRES database.

This example should store the state values using [Type 2 Slowly Changing Dimensions|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slowly_changing_dimension#Type_2:_add_new_row] data tables. 

The block information should be stored in a blocks table.  

The example should handle fork resolution.

column1: Handle Ethereum nonces correctly
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Currently they are ignored except when creating contract accounts. Below is a partial list of the additional work that needs to be done:
 * Whenever a contract is called, the nonce of the account associated with the contract must be incremented.
 * If a transaction submitted contains a nonce that does not match the (sender’s?) account, the transaction is invalid.
 * Burrow stores nonces as an int64 but since the nonce is a monotonically increasing value starting at 0, it probably makes more sense for this to be a uint64. Currently a type cast is performed when translating between the transaction payload and the EVM call.

column1: Research how to provide a Burrow EVM Web API
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The current form of the integration is not fully compatible with existing Solidity code and Javascript libraries. This task is to research how to provide a WEB API similar to that provided by the Burrow API to allow integration of existing javascript libraries.

The output of this task should be design and/or implementation tasks to provide this API.

column1: Standardize CLI Commands and Options
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Various commands for 0.8 were added with the assumption that we
 would at some point rename them for consistency across the project.
 Now seems an appropriate time to pick the final names and do the
 renaming.

Commands will use a '-' separator instead of '_', since this is
 more consistent with Linux commands in general.

The clients commands remain largely unchanged, with intkey_jvm being
 renamed to jvmsc (since it is an example of JVM smart contracts).

The client commands:
 sawtooth
 poet
 intkey
 jvmsc
 xo
 noop

The validator components will be prefixed with 'sawtooth-':

sawtooth-validator
 sawtooth-rest-api

Transaction processors will be renamed to conform to the general
 format of <family>-tp[-<lang>]. This organization is intended to
 sort the CLI commands by family instead of function. The commands
 become:

intkey-tp-go
 intkey-tp-java
 intkey-tp-javascript
 intkey-tp-python
 jvmsc-tp
 xo-tp-go
 xo-tp-javascript
 xo-tp-python
 noop-tp-go
 supplychain-tp
 poet-validator-registry-tp

 

 In an attempt to make the CLI options consistent across the various
commands, we will be modifying several often-used validator and REST
API options.

sawtooth-validator Usage
------------------------

We use a couple new terms here.  When peering is dynamic, the
validator will contact the "seed" nodes in it's discovery process;
once it has discovered a sufficient peer list, then it randomly
selects the peers from the discovered list.  The term "seed" is
new and replaces "join".  We have chosen to use "--bind" when
defining local endpoints and "--connect" when specifying remote
endpoints, across all commands.  The option "--endpoint" replaces
"--public-uri" and is the endpoint provided to peers.

The behavior of '--endpoint' will be to default to the network bind
address.  It should only really need to be specified when behind a
NAT or if it would be ambiguous (such as binding to 0.0.0.0).

When specifying 0MQ URIs, we will assume tcp:// by default if only
host:port is provided.

All equivalent:

NEW: sawtooth-validator \
  --bind=network:tcp://127.0.0.1:8800/ \
  --bind=component:tcp://127.0.0.1:40000/ \
  --endpoint=tcp://1.2.3.4:8800/ \
  --peering=dynamic \
  --seed=tcp://2.3.4.5:8800/ \
  --peer=tcp://2.3.4.5:8800/
NEW: sawtooth-validator \
  -B network:tcp://127.0.0.1:8800/ \
  -B component:tcp://127.0.0.1:40000/ \
  -E tcp://1.2.3.4:8800/ \
  -P=dynamic \
  -s tcp://2.3.4.5:8800/ \
  -p tcp://2.3.4.5:8800/
NEW: sawtooth-validator \
  -B network:127.0.0.1:8800 \
  -B component:127.0.0.1:40000 \
  -E 1.2.3.4:8800 \
  -P dynamic \
  -s 2.3.4.5:8800 \
  -p 2.3.4.5:8800
OLD: validator \
  --network-endpoint=tcp://127.0.0.1:8800/ \
  --component-endpoint=tcp://127.0.0.1:8800/ \
  --public-uri=tcp://1.2.3.4:8800/ \
  --peering=dynamic \
  --join=tcp://2.3.4.5:8800/ \
  --peers=tcp://2.3.4.5:8800/

FUTURE: sawtooth-validator \
  -B network,client:127.0.0.1:8800 \
  -B tp,client:127.0.0.1:40000 \
  -E 1.2.3.4:8800

The "FUTURE" case demonstrates why we have selected the particular
formatting of that argument.  It is intended to allow us to specify
classes of messages which are bound to a particular port.

validator.toml
--------------

The configuration file mirrors the command line options:

bind = [
  "network:tcp://127.0.0.1:8800/",
  "component:tcp://127.0.0.1:8800/"
]
endpoint = "tcp://1.2.3.4:8800/"
peering = "dynamic"
peers = [
  "tcp://2.3.4.5:8800/"
]
seeds = [
  "tcp://2.3.4.5:8800/"
]

sawtooth-rest-api Usage
-----------------------

The REST API's usage is similar, using '--bind' and '--connect'.

All equivalent:

NEW: sawtooth-rest-api \
  --bind=localhost:8080 \
  --connect=tcp://127.0.0.1:40000/ \
  --timeout=300
NEW: sawtooth-rest-api \
  -B localhost:8080 \
  -C tcp://127.0.0.1:40000/ \
  -t 300
NEW: sawtooth-rest-api \
  -B localhost:8080 \
  -C 127.0.0.1:40000 \
  -t 5m
OLD: rest_api \
  --host=localhost \
  --port=8080 \
  --timeout=300

rest-api.toml
-------------

connect = "tcp://127.0.0.1:40000"
bind = [
  "localhost:8800"
]
timeout = 300


Other commands will get similar changes, such as the TPs all using
'--connect'.

column1: Log File Support
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
We need to add logging support to all long-running processes (sawtooth-validator, sawtooth-rest-api, TPs).  By default, we should log both debug and error logs, with the ability to supply logging configuration to each command.

Since multiple of each process could be run on a single host, a unique ID must be added tot he log files to differentiate them.

This will look something like:

{noformat}
  /var/log/sawtooth/
    sawtooth-validator-ID-debug.log
    sawtooth-validator-ID-error.log
    sawtooth-rest-api-ID-debug.log
    sawtooth-rest-api-ID-error.log
    intkey-tp-go-ID-debug.log
    intkey-tp-go-ID-error.log
    intkey-tp-python-ID-debug.log
    intkey-tp-python-ID-error.log
    ...
    xo-tp-go-ID-debug.toml
    xo-tp-go-ID-error.toml
    xo-tp-python-ID-debug.toml
    xo-tp-python-ID-error.toml
    ...
    noop-go-ID-debug.toml
    noop-go-ID-error.toml
    supplychain-tp-ID-debug.toml
    supplychain-tp-ID-error.toml
    poet-validator-registry-ID-debug.toml
    poet-validator-registry-ID-error.toml
{noformat}

In addition to log file support, each process should support syslog.  This should be done in a configurable manner, such as that provided by the python logging library, log4j, and log4j-like libraries.  STL-358 will determine how this should be placed into configuration files.

column1: Embed log file configuration within component's config file
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Currently we have separate configuration files for logging.  We could instead embed the logging information inside the existing configuration files.

{noformat}
[logging]
version = 1
disable_existing_loggers = false

[logging.formatters.simple]
format = "[%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d [%(threadName)s] %(module)s %(levelname)s] %(message)s"
datefmt = "%H:%M:%S"

[logging.handlers.debug]
level = "DEBUG"
formatter = "simple"
class = "logging.FileHandler"
filename = "example-debug.log"

[logging.handlers.interconnect]
level = "DEBUG"
formatter = "simple"
class = "logging.handlers.RotatingFileHandler"
filename = "example-interconnect.log"
maxBytes = 5000000
backupCount=20

[logging.handlers.error]
level = "ERROR"
formatter = "simple"
class = "logging.FileHandler"
filename = "example-error.log"

[logging.loggers."sawtooth_validator.networking.interconnect"]
level = "DEBUG"
propagate = true
handlers = [ "interconnect"]

[logging.root]
level = "DEBUG"
handlers = [ "error", "debug"]
{noformat}

Need to determine the best approach for TPs supporting multiple languages, since the above is python specific.

column1: Design approach to expose block information to transaction processors
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Design a method of exposing block information to transaction processors.  In particular, block number, block hash, and block timestamp.

At least two approaches should be considered (S0=starting state, S1=final state; T=transaction; B=block):

1. Inserting transactions into the block to update state (keeping S0+T->S1); or
2. Supplying a method for TPs to get block information via 0MQ API (switching to S0+T+B->S1)

column1: Check the transaction_ids list in the batch header against the transaction list in the batch
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
As defined, transactions must be wrapped in a Batch, and must contain the public key of the batch signer in the batcher_pubkey field. So a transaction is only wrapped in a batch, a batch must contain the complete transactions that the transaction_id list in the batch header.

A new handler is needed that checks the transaction_ids list in the batch header against the transaction list in the batch. Batches which don't contain the complete transactions that the transaction_id list in the batch header would be dropped.

column1: Validator Registry does not remove Validator ID on re-enrollment
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
consensus.poet.families.sawtooth_validator_registry.validator_registry.processor.handler._update_validator_state(...)

Manages structures associated with validator admission.

On re-enrolling an existing anti-sybil ID (EPID), with a new Validator ID (OPK), the previous Validator ID will not be expunged from state, and the \{anti-sybil ID: Validator ID} map will not be updated appropriately.



Correct the method to remove the old Validator ID record from state and update the \{anti-sybil ID: Validator ID} map to include the new Validator ID.

column1: Resolve license issues uncovered by Fossology Scan
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
h2. Context

Hyperledger Sawtooth source files (pulled on June 5, 2017) were scanned by The Linux Foundation utilizing Fossology to determine license for files contained in the following repositories:
 * [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core.git]

From the Hyperledger Charter ([https://www.hyperledger.org/about/charter]) Section 13, all files that are included in Hyperledger projects should either be licensed with the Apache License, Version 2.0 for source code or Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License for documentation.
h2. Expected Behavior

All files should have license text included either directly or via a LICENSE file in the directory for files that cannot be modified to include a comment with the license text (think binary files).
h2. Actual Behavior

See attached file for results.
h2. Possible Fix

For files with Attribution license, ideally, we would replace those with Apache 2.0 files and dependencies; otherwise, we will need to go to the Hyperledger Governing board for exception.

For _ALL_ files that do not have a license included, the first step is to check with the contributor to ensure that the file can be released as Apache 2.0 or CC-BY-4.0. If the contributor agrees, the file should be modified to include the license. You can utilize [SPDX Identifiers|https://spdx.org/] to represent the correct license.

For those non-modifiable files, you will need to include a LICENSE file in the directory containing the license that the files are covered by. Here are a few examples of how this might be done:
 * [OPNFV Apex|https://github.com/opnfv/apex/blob/master/LICENSE.rst] -- this is an example of explicitly calling out Apache 2.0 for source code and CC-BY-4.0 for docs.
 * [containerd|https://github.com/containerd/containerd/blob/master/README.md] -- see notice at bottom. This also calls out the separate Apache / CC-BY-4.0 docs, and explicitly references the "docs" directory.

h2. Steps to Reproduce

Run code through Fossology (contact tkuhrt at linuxfoundation dot org) to have the source re-run after bug has been fixed.
column146: 09/Jun/17 4:49 AM;tkuhrt;Forgot to mention that the file (/validator/packaging/windows/sawtooth-validator.nsi) has license information that refers to a EULA.  We need to figure out what this is and what changes can be made to that one.;;;
column147: 31/Oct/17 4:20 AM;tkuhrt;Latest results attached.;;;
column148:
29/Nov/17 12:54 AM;tkuhrt;Uploaded results from 11/27 scan. Here are the highlights:
 * There are 3 non-Apache components still in the codebase, two under MIT and one under a Zlib-style license. These are all permissive licenses which will likely be acceptable to the Governing Board. But they will still require exception approvals from the GB, per Hyperledger's IP Policy.
 * There remain about 300 files in the repo that don't contain an Apache-2.0 or CC-BY-4.0 license within the file itself. These do not require exception approval, but would likely be mentioned in the license report for the committee/board as an area for future improvement.
 * We would recommend that the community looks at adding SPDX short-form identifiers to individual files, as a quicker and more efficient way to add licensing details.
 * Also, for this report, we are now counting separately any files that are completely empty (e.g., fully empty __init__.py files). These are now listed separately in the report from other files with content but no license info.;;;
column149:
30/Nov/17 4:14 AM;dan.middleton@intel.com;[~tkuhrt] what is the policy for docs and image files? I thought they were covered by the top level license - which declared them all to be CC 4?

If that's correct can we filter png, svg, pdf, and rst files from the scan? ;;;
column151:
04/Dec/17 6:51 PM;pschwarz;Do the completely empty files require license headers?

 

Another file type that cannot accept license header comments are any JSON files. ;;;
column152:
05/Dec/17 2:22 AM;tkuhrt;[~pschwarz] : Ideally, the empty files should also contain an SPDX short license comment

*// SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0*;;;
column153: 12/Dec/17 6:36 AM;pschwarz;I've add a trimmed down version of the spreadsheet with the remaining files to be versioned.  Some of which I'm not sure the license (CC or Apache), others I'm not sure how to license (e.g. PDF files internals);;;
column154:
23/Jan/18 4:42 AM;dan.middleton@intel.com;[~tkuhrt] with the board approval for the remaining items, I think this is done. 

If you agree can you mark as `done`?;;;

Check out the 2018-01 file for this list. It is found on the "No License Found" tab. Note that there are ones that have been excluded because we know these file types cannot have license text added. column162:
08/Aug/18 12:24 AM;tkuhrt;New upload sawtooth-2018-07-27.xls.
Notes for sawtooth scan 2018-07-27:

1) In the sawtooth-sabre repo, the file at /tp/Cargo.toml lists "Apache" as the license. Could this be updated to "Apache-2.0", to avoid any ambiguity in the metadata about which version of the Apache license applies?

2) The great majority of Sawtooth source code files contain Apache-2.0 notices. Thank you for all your help on this.

In the "No license found" tab of the spreadsheet, the files with "No license found" do not contain license notices that were detected from our scanning. Where reasonably possible, for those files that contain Hyperledger code, Apache-2.0 comments should be added. This can be done by adding a comment with an SPDX short-form identifier, such as:

    SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0

Note that the files in this tab listed as "third party directory", "excluded file extension" or "empty file" do not need to have these notices added.

3) Creative Commons Attribution 4.0, CC-BY-4.0, is the license for Hyperledger documentation. Many of the documentation files already have CC-BY-4.0 notices. For those Hyperledger documentation files that don't, consider adding notices to them, such as by using an SPDX short-form identifier:

    SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0

More information for #2 and #3 can be found on the Hyperledger wiki, at https://wiki.hyperledger.org/community/copyright-and-license-policy;;;
column163:
12/Oct/18 2:34 AM;tkuhrt;New upload sawtooth-2018-09-26.xlsx

Notes from sawtooth-2018-09-26.xlsx scan:
 * This was a special scan for the 1.1 branch of sawtooth-core (plus the master branch for the other Sawtooth repos).
 * The main question from the Legal Subcommittee would be about the /NOTICES files in *sawtooth-core* and *sawtooth-poet*. These files were not present for the final pre-release scan for 1.0 that the subcommittee reviewed earlier this year. Most of the components listed in these files may be coming from the developers' own scans or reviews. They describe components that do not appear to be contained within the source code repos themselves (so the FOSSology license scans I've run do not detect them).

From that file, the following software + licenses are the ones that may raise some particular concern with the Legal Subcommittee:
- *zeromq* (LGPL-3.0-only WITH ZeroMQ-linking-exception)
- *cchardet* (MPL-1.1)
- *zeromq jeromq* (MPL-2.0)
- *OpenSSL* (OpenSSL license)

For each of these software components, it would be very helpful to have the developers weigh in on the following questions:

A) Is this component actually included in the sawtooth repo source code? Or is it a build-time or install-time dependency?
B) What functionality does this component provide?
C) What functional portion(s) of Sawtooth use this component?
D) Is this component required for Sawtooth to function?
E) Are there alternative third-party OSS components that provide equivalent functionality?

The answers to these questions (A in particular) would help the Legal Subcommittee / GB evaluate whether to approve these as exceptions to the Hyperledger IP policy. 

 * In the *sawtooth-sabre* repo, the file at /tp/Cargo.toml lists "Apache" as the license. Could this be updated to "Apache-2.0", to avoid any ambiguity in the metadata about which version of the Apache license applies?
 * In the *sawtooth-next-directory* repo, there are three files in /processore/rbac_processor that have incomplete Apache-2.0 license headers. These files are listed in the "Wrong license statement" tab of the report. Can these be updated to include the full standard Apache-2.0 header?
 * The great majority of Sawtooth source code files contain Apache-2.0 notices. Thank you for all your help on this.

In the "No license found" tab of the spreadsheet, the files with "No license found" do not contain license notices that were detected from our scanning. Where reasonably possible, for those files that contain Hyperledger code, Apache-2.0 comments should be added. This can be done by adding a comment with an SPDX short-form identifier, such as:
    SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0
Note that the files in this tab listed as "third party directory", "excluded file extension" or "empty file" do not need to have these notices added. Similarly, some of the files that are listed just as "No license found" may be in a format where it's not reasonably possible to add a license notice, and that's fine if so.

 * Creative Commons Attribution 4.0, CC-BY-4.0, is the license for Hyperledger documentation. Many of the documentation files already have CC-BY-4.0 notices. For those Hyperledger documentation files that don't, consider adding notices to them, such as by using an SPDX short-form identifier:
    SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0

 

More information for the last two bullets can be found on the Hyperledger wiki, at [https://wiki.hyperledger.org/community/copyright-and-license-policy]
 ;;;

column165:

- *zeromq* (LGPL-3.0-only WITH ZeroMQ-linking-exception)
- *cchardet* (MPL-1.1)
- *zeromq jeromq* (MPL-2.0)
- *OpenSSL* (OpenSSL license)

They are included in the NOTICES file to facilitate binary distributions of Sawtooth.

As these 3rd party modules are not themselves "inbound contributions" do we still need to seek legal committee exceptions?;;;

column1: Update StateEntry proto, Get and Set Handlers for ContextManager, to handle null values
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The State interface, including proto definitions, doesn't handle null values and from the sdk's perspective null and empty bytes are the same. Because of how Protocol Buffers version 3 works, bytes fields have an empty bytes string as a default. This [Github issue |https://github.com/google/protobuf/issues/1606]gives Oneof fields as an alternative to null values. 

This task should be done in concert with updating the sdks to correctly return a null value from gets on the sdk state class, and also set a null value to an address using the sdk state class.

column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The State interface, including proto definitions, doesn't handle null values and from the sdk's perspective null and empty bytes are the same. Because of how Protocol Buffers version 3 works, bytes fields have an empty bytes string as a default. This [Github issue |https://github.com/google/protobuf/issues/1606]gives Oneof fields as an alternative to null values.

 

In concert with STL-399, update the sdks to handle null values.

column1: Implement Initial Private UTXO transaction Processor
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Create a Transaction Processor that implements handling of the described in the Private UTXO transaction processor spec: 

1) creating an asset type

2) transfer asset

3) convert asset to off DLT UTXO

4) transfer UTXO to UTXO

- IAS AVR should be stubbed out. 

5) Convert UTXO to on chain Asset

 

 

 

Implement TP test for this transaction processor using the Transaction Processor Test FrameWork

column1: Implement Initial UTXO CLI
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Create aa cli that can perform the following actions:

1) Submit a transaction to creating an asset type

2) Submit a transaction to transfer asset

3) Submit a transaction to asset to off DLT UTXO

4) Submit a transaction to transfer UTXO to UTXO

- no IAS AVR required.

5) Convert UTXO to on chain Asset

6) retrieve the current UTXO set.

7) Report current on ledger balances of an public key.

column1: Extend SupplyChain Rest API to provide StateQuery Information
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Extend the Supplychain rest API to be a StateExport Client and create historical and state indexes and REST api endpoints to query those indexes. 

 

These indexes should include what records an agent owns(with filters on record state, finalized or not), what application a agent has open(with filters by type?).

column1: Design stat collection library
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.

column1: Determine all the validator stat metrics to collect
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The output of this work should be a list of metrics the validator could/should log.  Descriptions of the metrics can be brief.  It does not need to include OS metrics, as those are collected with telegraph outside of the validator process.

This list does not need to be 100% complete - we can add metrics later.  However, it does need to be close enough to inform the design of the stats/metrics library; in particular, we need to know the different types of metrics.  For example, we know some metrics are additive (such as number of blocks published) and some might be set (current length of chain), while others might be an average (txn rate).
column146:
28/Jun/17 5:53 AM;GhadiShayban;Hopefully this is the right place for this:

Basic operational metrics we're interested in:
 * block progress per validator
 * number of transaction aborts
 * tx counter by family
 * tx latency by family
 * merkle tree "size" for some definition of size
 * known peer count (from the perspective of each peer)

I recommend *against* two things:

  UDP-based metrics (statsd) 
  "Average" metrics – you can always derive the averages from counters or gauges


We use [Prometheus.io|http://prometheus.io/] internally here, have had great success with it.  Pull-based metrics seem counterintuitive but they have significant advantages compared to UDP-based ("push") metrics like statsd.  It's conceptually very simple and if I were a betting man, prometheus will outlast influx / statsd.

[https://prometheus.io/docs/introduction/overview/]

[https://github.com/prometheus/client_python]

 ;;;
column147:
28/Jun/17 6:37 AM;Tom Barnes;Thanks Shayban.  I saw you comment on rocket chat last week and I'm taking a look at Prometheus.  I will also take into consideration your recommendations above.

In your internal code do you have a shim that makes it agnostic to the data collection tool, or are you "all in' with Prometheus?  Sawtooth may be deployed in data centers where other metrics tools are in use, and where consequently Prometheus instrumentation will not be helpful.;;;

column1: Solidity Developer Compatibility
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
This Epic has two phases:

1. Produce a design document detailing a solution which enables developers already using Ethereum Solidity language and tools to transition smoothly to working with Sawtooth's Burrow-based EVM transaction family.

2. Implement, document, and provide tests for Solidity Developer Compatibility per the design.


Enable existing Solidity smart contract developers to:
 # Migrate their existing Solidity smart contracts and the applications built around those smart contracts to Sawtooth from Burrow or Public Ethereum
 # Reuse the familiar Solidity tools solc and web3.js while developing for Sawtooth

column1: Design EVM permissioning model
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Design a model for setting Burrow-EVM account permissions within Sawtooth that can be integrated with the Burrow-EVM permission model (i.e., the code that already exists within the Burrow-EVM that is currently turned off). Check with the Burrow team to see if this scheme has changed in v0.17

column1: Implement EVM permissions
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Implement the permissions model defined in STL-448

column1: Define Burrow-EVM transaction receipts
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
After a transaction is executed, additional “substate” information should be stored about the transaction execution including:
 * Return Value from the EVM (see below).
 * Any logs that were produced (see below).
 * The address of the contract that was created, if applicable.
 * Any other information that can be stored from: [https://github.com/ethereum/wiki/wiki/JSON-RPC#eth_gettransactionreceipt]

This task should determine what information needs to be stored in the transaction receipts and define how the receipts will be stored so they can be searched and indexed inefficiently.

column1: Implement stored EVM return values
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Duplicate of STL-459

column1: Implement logging event handler within Burrow-EVM
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
A set of LOG instructions are defined by the EVM which can be used to place information into a separate “substate”. It is intended that these logs be stored in a manner that is easily indexed and searched. Smart contract languages have adopted the convention of using these LOG instructions to set up event pub/sub patterns.

The LOG opcodes in the burrow-evm rely on an event-handling system that is part of the burrow project. This will likely need to be preserved in order to use the EVM as it exists in the burrow project. This event handling should be preserved if possible and used to forward events to the Sawtooth event system.

column1: Update txn inputs/outputs to enable contract chaining
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Currently, contract chaining is not possible because only the address of the sender account and receiver account are passed as inputs and outputs when submitting a transaction.

To support contract chaining, it should be made possible to pass the burrow-EVM namespace prefix as inputs and output when submitting a transaction.

The inputs/outputs are set here:

[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/master/families/burrow_evm/src/sawtooth_burrow_evm/client/client.go#L60]

[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/master/families/burrow_evm/src/sawtooth_burrow_evm/client/client.go#L106]

column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The client features of Python SDK should be updated to match the functionality of the JavaScript SDK. Specifically this means adding a module for creating/encoding Batches and Transactions, as well as a signing module which can sign, verify, generate private keys, and generate public keys. Decisions must made about whether or not the root level signing module already satisfies those requirements, or should be replaced by this SDK.

 

Add any appropriate unit tests for the new functionality.

column1: Implement BlockStore replay tool
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Implement a tool which will replay the blocks contained in a block store through the scheduler/executor/context manager/TPs.

Initially, this tool is primarily for testing scheduler implementations and debugging.

This tool should make aggressive use of the schedulers, by default, spanning multiple blocks across a single scheduler.  It should also have options to make it behave closer to the journal (currently single block at a time).

This tools should print performance statistics as it operates.
column146: 16/Mar/21 4:59 AM;amundson;Duplicates https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/issues/2368;;;

column1: Handle txn in a predecessor's batch failing by replay of subsequent txns
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: For the parallel-scheduler, If [a, b, c] are a batch and [d, e, f] are a batch and d implicitly depends on a, if a is valid, but c is invalid, d and any subsequent txns should be re-run as if 'a' hadn't been run. This will cause more txns than are in the scheduler to be run, but there should be only 1 final txn_result per txn. After this task there should be unittests and yaml based scheduler tests for this functionality and the parallel scheduler should be passing them.

column1: IAS Proxy and Client
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Features needed to release IAS (Intel Attestation Service) proxy and client components.  At conclusion of this epic, the IAS proxy and client will be included in one or more Python packages which can be installed as debian packages.

column1: Create Package for IAS Client
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: The IAS client, because it is used by both the SGX enclave and the IAS proxy, needs to be put into its own package.

column1: Create Unit Tests for IAS Client
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: The IAS client, once moved to its own package, needs its own unit tests to verify that it behaves properly in the face of network errors (timeouts, HTTP error return codes, etc.).

column1: Create Package for IAS Proxy
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Once the PoET SGX code has been committed to the repository, the IAS proxy needs its own separate package.

column1: Create Proper Unit Tests for the IAS Proxy
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: The IAS proxy currently has unit tests that communicate with the real IAS server.  Unit tests need to be created to ensure that the proxy properly deals with errors.

column1: Update yaml scheduler tester to test gets from state
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: To find errors, and provide more of a guarantee that the state "seen" by the txn processor is correct in the parallel case it would be preferable to while running the scheduler using the run_scheduler method on the tester, to 'get' values that were inputs for the txn and assert that they are correct. When processing the yaml, collect the valid 'set' values to be asserted when run_scheduler is called.

column1: Update the ParallelScheduler to fail-fast on a batch
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Since batches are atomic, it would be preferable to not run any txns that don't need to be run. So after a txn fails, provide an INVALID_BATCH status to the TransactionExecutionResult. Provide unit-tests.

column1: Add another run_scheduler method to yaml scheduler tester
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: The order of next_transaction, set_transaction_result, finalize, and complete can vary widely, with only some being possible.  The run_scheduler method currently is greedy on next_transaction getting the possible next_transaction after each subsequent set of set_transaction_result. Another method should be written that is greedy on set_transaction_result.

column1: Write more yaml scheduler tests
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: These tests should include namespace inputs and outputs, mixed sizes of batches, batches that have predecessor transactions that are valid, with subsequent transactions in a batch that fail.

Related to STL-490.

column1: Separate sawtooth config cli commands
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Separate out the {{sawtooth config}} subcommand into a cli tool under the sawtooth settings family.  This change further highlights that this family is a reference implementation of a settings-change family. 

The new tool should be called {{st-settings}}.

Commands not removed from the core CLI tool should be the subcommands of 
* {{sawtooth config settings list}} - move up to {{sawtooth settings list}}

column1: Implement a state cache between the Burrow-EVM TP and validator
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Currently, a full state request is performed and the data received is deserialized every time information about an account or storage is requested from the validator. This is unnecessary overhead, since the state is guaranteed not to change in between requests to the validator, unless specifically changed by the processor.

To improve performance, a cache of account and storage information should be implemented between the Burrow-EVM Transaction Processor and the Validator. This could be implemented as part of the StateManager or SawtoothAppState classes, or possibly as a separate class. Relevant code is here:

[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/master/families/burrow_evm/src/sawtooth_burrow_evm/processor/handler/state_manager.go]

[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/blob/master/families/burrow_evm/src/sawtooth_burrow_evm/processor/handler/sawtooth_app_state.go]

column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.

column1: Define Database Schema
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.

column1: Create State Delta Subscriber
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Create a delta state subscriber that will consume state values for the SupplyChain transaction family and store them in a database. 

This task involves creating the subscriber, processing the events to insert values.  This client should handle disconnects and reconnects of the validator, delta catch-up, as well as fork resolution.

column1: Update ParallelScheduler to handle explicit dependencies
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
If a txn has explicit dependencies, it should first look to see if that txn is before it* in the scheduler, and then only if it is use that explicitly dependent txn as a gate on it being next transaction.

Because 'intkey workload' uses dependencies, the parallel scheduler won't work with intkey workload until this is done.

* We are relying on the completer to never allow the dependency to be after that batch with the transaction that lists the dependency.

column1: Split scheduler tests.py file into multiple test files

column32: The single test file for the schedulers in the parallel-scheduler branch is really long. It would make more sense to break it into several test files, possibly test_serial_scheduler, test_parallel_scheduler, test_scheduler.

column1: validator without access to log directory gives Traceback
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
If the validator does not have access to the log directory, it displays a Traceback:

{noformat}
ubuntu@ubuntu-xenial:~$ validator -vv
[16:35:39.292 INFO     path] Skipping path loading from non-existent config file: /etc/sawtooth/path.toml
[16:35:39.293 INFO     validator] Skipping validator config loading from non-existent config file: /etc/sawtooth/validator.toml
[16:35:39.293 INFO     keys] Loading signing key: /etc/sawtooth/keys/validator.priv
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/validator", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('sawtooth-validator==0.8.5', 'console_scripts', 'validator')()
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_validator/server/cli.py", line 223, in main
    name="validator-" + pubkey[:8])
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/sawtooth_validator/server/log.py", line 78, in log_configuration
    debug_handler = logging.FileHandler(log_filename + "-debug.log")
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/logging/__init__.py", line 1008, in __init__
    StreamHandler.__init__(self, self._open())
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/logging/__init__.py", line 1037, in _open
    return open(self.baseFilename, self.mode, encoding=self.encoding)
PermissionError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/var/log/sawtooth/validator-027aba6e-debug.log'
{noformat}

The desired behavior is something like:

{noformat}
$ validator
Error: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/var/log/sawtooth/validator-027aba6e-debug.log'
{noformat}

column1: Batches submitted via REST API during genesis are lost
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
When a batch is submitted via the REST API to a validator that is processing the genesis block, it will be lost.  

Steps to reproduce:

1. Create a genesis block with at least one sawtooth settings transaction
2. Start a validator process
3. Start a REST API process
4. Submit an intkey transaction (via intkey load, for example). 
5. Start {{tp_settings}}
6. Start {{tp_intkey_python}}

At this point, the genesis block will be created, but the intkey transaction(s) will not be processed.  

To fix this, either:

- the batch should be preserved in a pending queue (which would require journal being active)
- do not accept client messages until the genesis block is complete (probably the most desirable)

column1: Implement Trust Authorization
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The first step to enforcing on-chain connection authorization is to implement Trust Authorization. This should include the following:

Proto files for TrustAuthorization messages

Validator should expect a ConnectRequest and respond with a ConnectionResponse which includes roles available on that endpoint. 

Finally, 0ther Validators, TP for all sdk, and the Rest_api should respond with AuthorizationTrustRequest with its expected roles. The validator will respond with AuthorizationTrustResponse  and if accepted with roles allowed.

The network will then function as normal after this point.

column1: Implement Challenge Authorization
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Challenge Authorization should be used when enforcing connection against public keys. This should include:

Proto files for ChallengeAuthorization messages

Finally, requesting Validators will respond with AuthorizationChallengeRequest.

The validator will send a AuthorizationChallengeResponse, which include a payload that must be signed. 

The requesting validator will respond with a AuthorizationChallengeSubmit that includes the signature, public key, and requested roles

The validator will respond with AuthorizationChallengeResult and if accepted with roles allowed.

The network will then function as normal after this point.

column1: Implement Shared Secret Authorization
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Shared Secret Authorization should be used when enforcing connection that connected to a local validator. This should include:

Proto files for SharedSecrectAuthorization messages

Finally, requesting Validators will respond with AuthorizationSharedSecretRequest.

The  validator will respond with a AuthorizationSharedSecretResponse  and if the shared secret matches it will include the roles allowed.

The network will then function as normal after this point.

column1: Rename cli commands
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Various commands for 0.8 were added with the assumption that we
would at some point rename them for consistency across the project.
Now seems an appropriate time to pick the final names and do the
renaming.

Commands will use a '-' separator instead of '_', since this is
more consistent with Linux commands in general.

The clients commands remain largely unchanged, with intkey_jvm being
renamed to jvmsc (since it is an example of JVM smart contracts).

The client commands:
sawtooth
poet
intkey
jvmsc
xo
noop

The validator components will be prefixed with 'sawtooth-':

sawtooth-validator
sawtooth-rest-api

Transaction processors will be renamed to conform to the general
format of <family>-tp[-<lang>]. This organization is intended to
sort the CLI commands by family instead of function. The commands
become:

intkey-tp-go
intkey-tp-java
intkey-tp-javascript
intkey-tp-python
jvmsc-tp
xo-tp-go
xo-tp-javascript
xo-tp-python
noop-tp-go
supplychain-tp
poet-validator-registry-tp

column1: Performance Workload
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Design and implement a Hyperledger Sawtooth transaction family and workload generation client suitable for benchmarking and stress testing the system. The tool will support capture and replay of workloads to ensure consistency across performance testing runs.

column1: Sawtooth Performance Analysis
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Produce a Hyperledger Sawtooth Performance Analysis Report using the performance workload tools delivered by Performance Workload. The Performance Analysis Report will describe the behavior of an instance of Hyperledger Sawtooth consisting of at least five validator nodes and will include coverage of network, storage, and compute system resources. The report should enable the identification of potential system bottlenecks.

column1: PoET Release
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Produce Ubuntu 16.04 deb packages and corresponding documentation for the PoET SGX component. The deliverable will be in the form of a repeatable build and release process integrated with the project’s existing CI and release process. The deliverable will also include the first versions of the built packages and associated documentation made available for public consumption.

column1: Remove MustEncode() and MustDecode() from Go SDK
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Remove the MustEncode() and MustDecode() methods from the Go SDK and replace all calls with hex.EncodeToString() and hex.DecodeString() from the "encoding/hex" Go library. These methods cause panics instead of handling errors gracefully, which is no longer desired. Handle the error returned from DecodeString().

column1: Add option to wait for transactions to commit in Burrow-EVM client
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The Burrow-EVM client only checks that transactions were accepted by the REST API. It does not check to see if the transaction was committed or what the error was. An argument should be added to client methods which, if set, will cause the client to block until:
 1. A timeout has been reached, at which point it should return and error
 2. The transaction has been committed, at which point it should return normally
 3. There was a problem committing the transaction, at which point it should return a useful error

Update the integration tests to use this feature once implemented.

column1: Add --wait flag to seth commands
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Add a --wait flag to seth commands that submit transactions which sets the wait option for the client.

column1: Remove redundant encoding/decoding needed for keys and addresses in the Burrow-EVM transaction family
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The path an address takes from when it is passed as an argument to
seth to when it is used to update state should be traced and the type and number
of transformations should be simplified. This may mean storing EVM addresses as
strings in state to reduce the amount of encoding/decoding in which case it
should only be needed in transaction handlers prior to interacting with
SawtoothAppState.

column1: Track and Trade
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
This Epic has two phases:

1. Produce a design document which describes necessary updates/modifications to the Supplychain transaction family to support missing features from the Demonet Fish example, including:
-Adding support for custom meta data on Supplychain Records
-Adding support for Telemetry Data on Supplychain Records
-Adding a Track and Trade specific REST query and reporting API using state export and native key access
-Adding Track and Trade specific submission API endpoint support which includes remote signing for all transactions
-User Interface Wireframes for the existing Supplychain functionality and the functionality included in this design deliverable

2. Implement and test the “Track and Trade” design.

column1: Create User Interface Wireframes for the existing Supplychain functionality and Track And Trade enchancement
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.

column1: Produce custom metadata design
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Provide a design for custom metadata on the Record and Agent state structures.  This must support at least key-value pairs of strings.  

Updating this data should be only allowed by the owner of the structures (either the Agent or the current owner of the Record).  

Include the necessary changes to the supply chain database schema and state delta subscriber output.

Related to, and possibly supersedes STL-314

column1: Produce Telemetry data design
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:

column1: Design enhanced Supplychain REST API Design with reporting endpoints
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: The current supplychain REST endpoints only supply basic queries of data.  Provide a design for a broader set of REST endpoint which can perform queries against the data filtering on the domain-specific fields, as well as those that can answer queries based on the relationships between the domain-specific structures.

column1: Design domain specific transaction submission endpoint with server side signing
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Provide the design for an endpoint which can:

* Accept domain-specific transaction content.  For example, this could be submitted in JSON.
* Create a transaction body and batch for submission
* Sign the transaction using server-side stored keys.

The design is open to method on how these keys are associated with the submitter.  Most likely, this will also require one or more authentication endpoints.

column1: use consistent hash function in merkle-radix trie address construction
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
We should consistently use truncated sha512 as the hash function for creating state addresses. There's occasional use of sha256. This does not present a defect as the same amount of bits are used. I understand though, that sha512 is recommended for performance reasons.

 

Updates to at least this code:

consensus/poet/families/sawtooth_validator_registry/validator_registry/processor/handler.py:106

And this doc:

docs/source/app_developers_guide/address_and_namespace.rst:55

docs/source/app_developers_guide/address_and_namespace.rst:120

 

Possibly other places.

This issue appears to be inconsistent with the architectural principles of both v1.2, v1.3, and the main branch, and so we are updating this status to won't fix. If you believe this is in error, please help our migration efforts and re-open this issue in Github Issues at https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/issues.

Explanation: the addressing scheme doesn't particularly matter as long as it is well-defined by the smart contract's definition. sha256 and sha512 are both fine approaches when hashing is used.;;;

Appropriate methods on the context manager and _StateContext are needed.

column1: compulsory counter cleanup code
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Need to release monotonic counters used by poet sgx enclave when they are no longer needed.

 

PoET validator code should call the release signup data method in the enclave to release the monotonic counter.

Proposed policy:

1. whenever k-test expires release signup data. 

2. on uninstall

Other times may create issues with forks. We keep signup info in a little database to cover the case that a validator is registered differently on different forks. Releasing the counter prematurely will effectively unregister the validator.
column146:
26/Aug/17 12:50 AM;cintel;PR 757 Did not complete this task: https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/pull/757

Appears to only releases the monotonic counter if the block limit(k test) is claimed on a signup info, if the signup info is registered on an abandoned fork or is not committed to the chain(included in the wrong block) the counters do not appear to be released.

A policy on how deep the fork is before release of a signup data may be appropriate. Once a fork has been abandoned for n blocks the signup data should be released. 

 

 

 ;;;

column1: PoET SGX implementation deviates from spec
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
PoET SGX Implementation deviates from spec on use of monotonic counters.

An attacker could work around the anti-sybil protections to increase their odds of winning a block.

This attack does not compromise State integrity or liveness, but it does compromise fairness.

 

Limitations:
 * An attacker must control a valid registered PoET endpoint.
 * All winning blocks will still be associated with the registered identity.
 * Defense in depth features, will limit the impact of the attack.
 * > z-test will prevent winning beyond network defined limits.
 * > SGX will limit total number of enclaves the machine can run (limited monotonic counters and other resources)

 

Defect:

The enclave does not destroy its poet validator signup info if the monotonic counter is lost.

 

Theoretic Attack:
 # An attacker must control a valid registered PoET endpoint.
 # Attacker launches the enclave,
 # call the ecall_Terminate() function to release the monotonic counter.
 # Launch multiple poet enclaves which each then create their own counters without knowledge of other enclave instances.
 # Counter binding to the signup info is lost.
 # Each enclave could then independently generate a new wait timer increasing the odds of winning a block.
 # The resulting wait certificate will pass validator registry checks because it is still signed with the registered poet key.

column1: Add handling for invalid signupdata
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
It is possible for signupdata to be corrupted. This could include file errors or release of the monotonic counter.

The enclave will throw an exception but the poet code in the validator process should have additional handling. 

It should detect that the signup data is no longer valid and that it must re-signup. 

This handling should be added to the poet_block_publisher around calls to create_wait_timer and create_wait_certificate.

Possibly update unseal_signup_data (particularly in the sgx code) to check the counter and return a distinct indication that the signup_data is unusable. Then use the unseal method as a guard in front of the create wait timer and certificate calls.

column1: JavaScript SDK: apply function handle undefined return values gracefully
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: The apply method in a JS TransactionHandler will break if anything other than a Promise is returned, including when receiving `undefined` from an apply method with no return statement. The SDK should gracefully handle "no-op" apply methods that return nothing.

column1: JavaScript SDK: "unwrapped" InvalidTransaction errors unhandled
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: When creating a JS TransactionHandler, an InvalidTransaction thrown within the apply function will not be properly handled by the SDK unless it is wrapped in a Promise first. These unwrapped errors should be handled and turned into correct responses to the validator.

column1: JavaScript SDK: reorganize structure and exported modules for publishing
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The JavaScript SDK should be reorganized to be better suited to publishing.
 * Remove files unnecessary for the end user, like the compile protobuf script.
 * Reevaluate exported modules to make the following features easily and sensibly accessible:
 ** clients
 ** transaction processors
 ** zmq client handlers
 ** zmq delta subscriptions
 ** protobuf definitions
 * Expand protobuf definitions to include delta export protobufs, and any others necessary for the above use cases.

column1: Implement remaining BatchInjector methods
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Only the BatchInjector.block_start() method is currently supported, but 3 more methods were defined in the design doc: before_batch, after_batch, and block_end. These were not added because they were not needed for "Solidity Developer Compatibility", but should be added in order to complete the original design.

column1: Change default REST API port to 8008
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Currently the Sawtooth REST API defaults to `localhost:8080`, which is common enough that it is likely to conflict with many web services developers may be running. This default should be changed to `localhost:8008`, which is less likely to cause collisions, is still a common HTTP port, and happens to be exactly twice the validator's default port.

This task includes changing _every_ default in sawtooth-core which expects to find the REST API at `localhost:8080`. This will include many CLIs and possible some other components as well.

column1: Make doc changes from STL-708
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Incorporate changes from --------STL-708-------- - Review Current Docs for Outdated and Inaccurate information. 

Summary of changes from Andi: 
 * Change IntKey to IntegerKey throughout, unless it's the actual intkey command
 * In SysAdmin Guide/Log Configuration/Default and elsewhere: Update validator log files names (no numeric string in validator-debug.log and validator-error.log)
 * In ApDev Guide/Address & Namespace Design: Change "configuration transaction family" to "settings transaction family"
 * In CLI References/IntegerKey: Mark "intkey generate" and "intkey populate" as deprecated (use "intkey create_batch" instead)
 * Correct Settings transaction family info: The transaction header family_name is sawtooth_settings (not sawtooth_config) 
 * In Validator Registry Transaction Family Specification/Execution: The validator_registry transaction is broadcast (not injected); remove "at this time" and "is needed" sentences.
 * In Community/Join the Discussion/Chat: Update hashtags
 * In Community/Contributing/Commit Process: Remove info about ENABLE_INTEGRATION_TESTS and update the passing lint output.
 * Other minor technical and wording/spelling/formatting fixes as marked in the printed review draft

Remaining questions and follow-up work: 
 * *Shawn*: Should I remove the PoET section from the Introduction?  (Andi commented that PoET isn't actually part of Sawtooth.) Or merge it into the Consensus section?  Or ... ? 
 See:  [http://intelledger.github.io/0.9/introduction.html#proof-of-elapsed-time-poet] 
  
 * *Cian*: Please review the Journal section (in the Architecture chapter) and supply corrections as necessary.
 See: [http://intelledger.github.io/0.9/architecture/journal.html] 
  
 * *Andi* and *Dan*: "Signing Transactions" (in the Core Developer's Guide) still has 0.7 information. Please identify the changes needed to bring this content into our current era.
 See: [http://intelledger.github.io/0.9/core_developers_guide/signing_transactions.html|http://intelledger.github.io/0.9/core_developers_guide/signing_transactions.html?highlight=signing] 
  
 * *Adam*: The Seth CLI overview needs a link to the Etherium Contract ABI.  Should it be the same as the link to the wiki in the "ABI Formatting" section? 
 See: [http://intelledger.github.io/0.9/cli/seth.html] 
 and: [http://intelledger.github.io/0.9/cli/seth.html#abi-formatting] 
  
 * *Andi*: Please supply info for the Validator Registry Transaction Family Specification section:
  + State: The new proto for ValidatorInfo  and the nonce to add to SignUpInfo 
  + Transaction Header: New settings addresses for the transaction header inputs & outputs (sawtooth.poet. ...) and clarification on how to change the last sentence about anti_sybil_id.
 See: [http://intelledger.github.io/0.9/transaction_family_specifications/validator_registry_transaction_family.html] 
  
 * *Shawn*: Should I remove the Examples chapter?
 See: [http://intelledger.github.io/0.9/examples.html]

column1: Add CLI flags to Javascript TPs
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Javascript TPs blow up when passed CLI flags:

```

ubuntu@ubuntu-xenial:/project/sawtooth-core/bin$ xo-tp-javascript -h

> xo_javascript@1.0.0 start /project/sawtooth-core/sdk/examples/xo_javascript
> node index.js "-h"

/project/sawtooth-core/sdk/examples/xo_javascript/node_modules/zeromq/lib/index.js:510
 this._zmq.connect(addr);
 ^

Error: Invalid argument
 at Error (native)
 at Socket.connect (/project/sawtooth-core/sdk/examples/xo_javascript/node_modules/zeromq/lib/index.js:510:13)
 at Stream.connect (/project/sawtooth-core/sdk/examples/xo_javascript/node_modules/sawtooth-sdk/messaging/stream.js:73:18)
 at TransactionProcessor.start (/project/sawtooth-core/sdk/examples/xo_javascript/node_modules/sawtooth-sdk/processor/index.js:52:18)
 at Object.<anonymous> (/project/sawtooth-core/sdk/examples/xo_javascript/index.js:34:22)
 at Module._compile (module.js:570:32)
 at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:579:10)
 at Module.load (module.js:487:32)
 at tryModuleLoad (module.js:446:12)
 at Function.Module._load (module.js:438:3)

npm ERR! Linux 4.4.0-53-generic
npm ERR! argv "/usr/bin/node" "/usr/bin/npm" "start" "--" "-h"
npm ERR! node v6.11.4
npm ERR! npm v3.10.10
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! xo_javascript@1.0.0 start: `node index.js "-h"`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the xo_javascript@1.0.0 start script 'node index.js "-h"'.
npm ERR! Make sure you have the latest version of node.js and npm installed.
npm ERR! If you do, this is most likely a problem with the xo_javascript package,
npm ERR! not with npm itself.
npm ERR! Tell the author that this fails on your system:
npm ERR! node index.js "-h"
npm ERR! You can get information on how to open an issue for this project with:
npm ERR! npm bugs xo_javascript
npm ERR! Or if that isn't available, you can get their info via:
npm ERR! npm owner ls xo_javascript
npm ERR! There is likely additional logging output above.

npm ERR! Please include the following file with any support request:
npm ERR! /project/sawtooth-core/sdk/examples/xo_javascript/npm-debug.log
```
JS TPs should use the same flags as the Python commands:

```

ubuntu@ubuntu-xenial:/project/sawtooth-core/bin$ xo-tp-python -h
usage: xo-tp-python [-h] [-v] [-V] [endpoint]

positional arguments:
 endpoint Endpoint for the validator connection

optional arguments:
 -h, --help show this help message and exit
 -v, --verbose Increase output sent to stderr
 -V, --version print version information

```

column1: Consider removing -vv from "sawtooth sawtooth-validator" in Ubuntu procedure
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
In "Installing and Running Sawtooth/Using Sawtooth on Ubuntu 16.04", the command to start the validator includes the -vv option.  The problem: The extra-verbose output produces so many DEBUG messages that it's difficult to see the "interesting" log messages - that is, the messages that later steps say to look for.

If there's a reason to have the extra-verbose output, the doc should include a better way to find the relevant log messages (which might mean explaining where the log files are).

column1: Get rid of `xo init`
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: `xo init` is stateful, unintuitive, and out of step with the rest of the CLI commands. `–url` and `–username` flags should be added to the other `xo` commands, giving for example `xo take game 3 --url rest-api:8080 --username ubuntu`. This is extra typing, but probably nobody is going to be using `xo` enough for the reduction in typing to be worth the complexity of the `init` command.

column1: LMDB Page Full - Block Size
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column146: 13/Mar/18 3:11 AM;drozd;See comment on https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/STL-786;;;

column1: LMDB Page Full - State Value
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column146:
10/Mar/18 1:53 AM;drozd;The LMDB docs describe the PageFullError as an internal error ([https://lmdb.readthedocs.io/en/release/#lmdb.PageFullError)|https://lmdb.readthedocs.io/en/release/#lmdb.PageFullError).], so it probably cannot be triggered by any specific Sawtooth actions. Further, LMDB has an overflow mechanism to handle large values (https://lmdb.readthedocs.io/en/release/#storage-efficiency-limits). There have been sporadic reports of this error cropping up around database deletes, but current Sawtooth workloads don't do deletes.

In any case, there's isn't enough information here to act on. At a minimum, error logs should be provided, and ideally a copy of the affected database.;;;

column1: Add unschedule_incomplete_batches() to Scheduler
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
In order to create blocks when the consensus module deems a node to have "won the block", the scheduler needs to discard any unprocessed batches.  Otherwise, the remaining batches' processing time may extend past the window of opportunity for claiming the block.

Add a {{scheduler.unschedule_incomplete_batches()}} function, which takes any uncompleted transactions and removes them from the schedule.

The flow should be:
{code:java}
scheduler.unschedule_incomplete_batches()
scheduler.finalize()
scheduler.complete(block=True){code}

column1: Create PoET liveness test
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The current PoET tests (test_poet_smoke, test_dynamic_network) are insufficient for gating PRs. They only test that the nodes are in consensus after a period of time. This means that the test will succeed even if no blocks are published after the genesis block.

In the interest of getting LR networks to pass, an additional integration test will be created to test that PoET is behaving correctly. The test should be an abbreviate version of the LR network tests. At a minimum, it should test that:
1. Blocks are being published at approximately the correct rate. (liveness)

2. Batches are being consumed at approximately the correct rate. (liveness)

3. Blocks contain batches. (liveness)

4. The nodes stay in consensus. (correctness)

column32: Make consensus-related changes to Hyperledger Sawtooth in preparation for future consensus algorithm integration. These changes will be consistent with the consensus design work from 2017 Q4, with changes necessary for rBFT and separation of consensus state from global state. Specifically, this will include separation of consensus into another process and implementing a Python consensus engine SDK for use by PoET and a Rust consensus engine SDK.

column1: /batch_status API hangs when id is an empty string
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Reported by Graham from Nettitude:

As part of a security assessment of Sawtooth, Nettitude has been fuzzing the REST API, and has found a class of queries which can cause the connection to hang.

This is undesirable from a security perspective, because it can be utilised increase the potency of a denial-of-service attack: whilst the connection remains open, it consumes resources on the server. 

The endpoint in question is “/batch_status”
 * If this is called with no id parameter, or an empty id parameter, then it returns immediately with in error message (code 66).
 * If it is supplied with one or more invalid but non-empty batch ids, then these are correctly reported as ‘invalid transactions’.
 * However, if it is presented with the empty string as a batch id, the request hangs until it times out after five minutes.

The simplest way to reproduce this effect is with a URL of the form:

[http://rest-api:8080/batch_status?id]=,

however a comma before or after a list of valid batch IDs will have a similar effect.

The root cause appears to be incomplete validation of the request by the REST API before it is passed onto the validator.

Beyond this specific issue, there does appear to be a lost opportunity here to perform more thorough validation within the REST API before data is passed on to the 0MQ interface. I can appreciate that there’s a desire to respect the DRY principle here, and I’m not advocating large-scale duplication of code from the validator to the REST API. However, there would be value in (for example) checking that arguments which are to be passed onwards as block, batch or transaction IDs do in fact consist of the appropriate number of hex digits.
column146:
18/Nov/17 2:53 AM;Tom Barnes;Additional comments from Graham (11/17/2017):

Further to the report below, some further classes of query which can cause a connection to the REST API to hang:
 * Queries to /receipts, with a list of two or more IDs, one or more of which are empty (essentially the same behaviour as previously reported for /batch_status).
 * Some types of query to /receipts containing NUL characters. This has not been fully characterised, but I now have 4 examples (including one where the zeros are in the endpoint path rather than the query string).

All of this would be covered by the argument validation recommended previously, however this does highlight the need for validation across the API as a whole rather than focussing on known conditions affecting individual endpoints, and for NUL characters to be handled appropriately. (Python should generally have no difficulty handling strings containing NULs, however I can imagine problems arising during serialisation/deserialization, and/or if modules are imported which have been implemented in C.);;;

column1: Make the BlockValidator and ChainController less tightly coupled
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Even though the BlockValidator will be separate from the ChainController, they are still tightly coupled because:
1. The ChainController manages blocks in process and blocks pending
2. The ChainController acts as an intermediary between the completer and BlockValidator
3. The ChainController creates the consensus module used by the BlockValidator for validation when the BlockValidator could do this
4. The BlockValidator keeps track of the chain head and validation results contain the chain head instead of the previous block.

column1: Closing state delta websocket renders the REST API unusable
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
When a websocket connection is opened, then subsequently closed, the REST API becomes unresponsive to subsequent HTTP state GETs.

When turning up the logging, it is apparent that the REST API has sent a protobuf request to the validator, but is stalled on receiving a response.

 

The attached logs of REST API + Validator show this sequence:

GET some state (Successful)

open a websocket (Successful until...)

close websocket

Then GET state on the REST API (sends the request to validator, stalls on response)
column146: 10/Nov/17 6:01 AM;GhadiShayban;We have seen issues under other scenarios where the REST API cannot communicate with the validator, despite not receiving a disconnect.  However, this specific path through web sockets was reliable to reproduce.;;;
column147: 21/Nov/17 1:21 AM;jaredcorduan;We were able to recreate the exact same issue on master (master as of last Friday, Nov 17).;;;
column149: 29/Nov/17 5:06 AM;GhadiShayban;[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/pull/1185] clears up the bug for us. Thank you Peter.;;;

column1: Replay attack protection in Sawtooth challenge authentication
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Reported by Graham at Nettitude:

As part of the Nettitude assessment of Sawtooth, I’ve been looking at whether the Challenge authentication method provides adequate protection against replay attacks.

It appears to go some way towards this: when an AuthorizationChallengeRequest is received, the validator replies with an AuthorizationChallengeResponse containing a 64-byte random payload. The client must reply AuthorizationChallengeSubmit containing a signed copy of the random payload. Since the payload changes for each exchange, the signature should too.

The only problem is that the validator does not appear to keep a copy of the random payload that was sent. Instead it trusts the copy of the payload sent back by the client, without checking that it is the same as the challenge issued.

I haven’t currently developed this as far as a practical exploit, and it is possible there is something I’ve missed. For example, even without recording the challenge, you could conceivably make the exchange secure by recording previously-used payloads. However I have looked, and have not found anything of that nature.

Grateful for a view as to whether there are any mitigations that I’ve overlooked, or if this is a potential vulnerability
column146: 28/Nov/17 3:54 AM;pschwarz;This has been fixed in [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/pull/1134]. It probably should be verified against the criteria above.;;;

column1: CORS configuration in Sawtooth REST API
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Reported by Graham at Nettitude:

As part of the Nettitude assessment of Sawtooth, I’ve been looking at how the REST API handles CORS.

This is configured to be fully permissive: whenever a pre-flight request containing an ‘Origin’ field is received, the value of that field is reflected back as ‘Access-Control-Allow-Origin’.

For most web services this would be a clear-cut security weakness, however I would not go that far in this case because:
 * It is clearly not an oversight (the code goes out of its way to allow the requests).
 * So far as I’ve been able to determine, the Sawtooth REST API does not itself make any use of cookies, HTTP authentication, or any other tokens that could be targeted by an XSRF attack.

However, I have identified two residual concerns:
 * I found some instructions at [https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/releases/latest/sysadmin_guide/rest_auth_proxy.html] for putting the REST API behind an authenticating proxy. My understanding is that proxy servers vary somewhat in terms of which headers they preserve, but there seems to be at least a possibility that XSRF could be an issue.
 * It does give attackers a useful extra option if attacks can be launched via the web browsers of unwitting third parties.

For these reasons I would recommend that the CORS behaviour should at least be configurable, and preferably set to non-permissive by default. I’d also recommend using a wildcard (‘*’) in preference to reflecting the origin field, unless there is a good reason not to, as this is less susceptible to XSRF.
column146:
28/Nov/17 3:13 AM;pschwarz;CORS was removed from the Sawtooth REST api, with the expectation that it would be enabled properly via a proxy server (similar to the same expectation around HTTP authentication).  Relevant PR: https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/pull/1114

E.g. an Apache server set up as a proxy could also handle CORS headers;;;

column1: File permissions for sawtooth private key
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Reported by Graham at Nettitude:

As part of the Nettitude assessment of Sawtooth, I’ve found that a default installation does not restrict access to the validator private key, located at “/etc/sawtooth/keys/validator.priv”.

This was found to be an issue with both the current stable Ubuntu packages and the most recent nightly build of the same. The installation and configuration procedure was as follows:

apt-get install sawtooth

sawadm keygen

 

The following file and directory modes were found:

drwxr-xr-x /etc/sawtooth

drwxr-xr-x /etc/sawtooth/keys

-rw-r--r-- /etc/sawtooth/keys/validator.priv

-rw-r--r-- /etc/sawtooth/keys/validator.pub

 

It was then confirmed that the private key could be accessed from an unprivileged account.

Running the validator in a separate docker container (as will often be the case) strongly mitigates this issue, however it would be imprudent to assume that configuration.

At a minimum, Nettitude would recommend changing the default file mode for the private key file from 644 to 600. Traditional UNIX philosophy would be to leave the public key as 644, but for a security-critical application like this there may be a case for restricting the entire hierarchy from /etc/sawtooth downwards (depending on what adverse impact, if any, this would have).

There are a number of other files and directories with public read access, and I’m currently in the process of looking to see if there is any security impact, but it is likely that the above private key is the most serious.

column1: BlockCache removes predecessors required for valid Chain
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
There is a race condition that occasionally causes blocks to be removed from the chain controller's block cache in between the time they are added and the time that their parent is validated, causing block validation of some fork to fail due to a missing predecessor. This can result in a network fork. Messages of this sort typically accompany the issue:

[2018-01-24 16:54:18.188 [Thread-53] block_validator INFO] Block 32ebbc5e2741491264219d21ad5a0a0010b26fb380285e7722499793d2bbdecf10bb11163b080eb400a4dceee88998d20aeb13b0742125cdd5fe
b6af1cc305e9 (block_num:2295, state:7788e8dc9100904877b574da742d09dcea602e7801f40fb881df1a46d2c4bfbb, previous_block_id:6493b4e64bb4157cd42103c57e11e015f7e8bc3b0c0167b7dfce1d96e405f
3466623d2e66aca8380e4ac99589fe60033d1f478c2fa23229d83ffe7232afcfb78) rejected due to missing predecessor 6493b4e64bb4157cd42103c57e11e015f7e8bc3b0c0167b7dfce1d96e405f3466623d2e66aca
8380e4ac99589fe60033d1f478c2fa23229d83ffe7232afcfb78

10/May/18 6:47 AM;dan.middleton@intel.com;a second fix is slated for the next release (probably v1.0.5)

[https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/commit/10526abff5b5513aee124919830e07fe908cbe25]

That fix catches another corner case, but the full remedy for this condition is to change the caching mechanism entirely. The design for that is here:

My certificate was made by this tutorial: [https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/how-to-create-self-signed-certificates-for-use-with-intel-sgx-remote-attestation-using]

and i got for result these files: client.cnf, client.crt, client.key, client.pfx, client.req 
 So i renamed client.key to sgx-certificate.pem and then i used it as shown in the tutorial for configuring sawtooth with sgx

I have ubuntu 16.04 with all the updates in a physical enviroment.

column1: Relax PoET registration freshness requirement
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Validator registration requires a nonce referencing the latest block.

That is overly restrictive. The freshness goal is to make it unlikely that a validator was revoked from the EPID group at the time of registration.

Something on the order of 10 blocks should still be more than sufficient.

The current harm from the 1 block requirement is that it's very likely that a validator's signup will fail in proportion to the load on the network. i.e. the signup transaction can't be guaranteed to commit within 1 block of the validator creating the registration transaction.

 

Update code and Spec.
column146:
09/Dec/17 2:09 AM;dan.middleton@intel.com;resolved in [https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-core/pull/1191]

 ;;;

column1: Fix Network Permissioning Test
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Fix the Network Permissioning Test to make it more predictable and less failure-prone.  The current behavior of the test causes frequent timeouts and failures that are not necessarily indications that the test is failing due to a regression.

 

This test should be:

 - more predictable, in terms of blocks produced, and when.

 - complete in a predictable amount of time.
