column1: State Delta Events: Filter state deltas based on addresses in attributes
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Filter the StateDelta objects in the opaque event data by the addresses in the attributes of the object.  This prevents unnecessary state from being sent to uninterested parties.  Additionally, it removes a step for the end user of needing to filter out the items based on the address provided in the attributes.

column1: TP Create Account

column32:
After this story the marketplace-tp will be tested to be able to handle a CreateAccount txn:
 * Be able to set an Account in state
 * Follow validation rules
 ** The public key of the txn signer does not already have an account.

column1: TP Create Holding
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
After this story the marketplace-tp will be tested to be able to handle a CreateHolding txn
 * Set a Holding in State
 * Follow validation rules
 ** The Holding id must not already belong to a holding.
 ** The account must exist.
 ** The account must be owned by the txn signer.
 ** The holding/Asset must exist.
 ** If the quantity is greater than 0, the txn signer must be an owner of the asset.

column1: Validator forward progress occasionally halts on cessation of input workload
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Using smallbank-tp-go and submitting smallbank workload, a pending queue of several thousand batches was built up. At the point where the workload was interrupted, block publishing ceased (the system appeared to be in a hung state). When workload was resumed, block publishing continued, and kept going after a second stoppage of the workload process.
column146: 02/Feb/18 2:04 AM;adamludvik;This should be resolved as part of the parallelism hint to the validator.;;;

column1: Transaction execution does not resume occasionally on stop/start of go transaction processors
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Occasionally, when smallbank-tp-go is stopped and started against a running validator with work to do, transactions fail to be sent to the newly connected tp.

NOTE: I do not think the Go TPs drain their work queues when a reconnect happens.

column1: Investigate discrepancy between volume of sent TP_PROCESS_REQUESTS and transaction execution count
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: In the LR tests, we are seeing an unexpectedly high volume of TP_PROCESS_REQUEST messages sent from the validators to the transaction processors vs. the received TP_PROCESS_RESPONSE messages and the count of executed transactions. The expected behavior is that these are all the same. Investigate the source of the discrepancy and verify that the execution of transactions is not resulting in a large number of duplicate/retried messages.
column146: 01/Feb/18 12:40 AM;pschwarz;This was a product of our measurements being mis-computed between the two measurements.  This resulted in the false discrepancy here.;;;

column1: Create Seth account fails unless nonce specified
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The Seth transaction processor does not accept transactions to create an account unless a nonce is set explicitly with the `seth` CLI tool.

The following interaction shows a test user being created, based on the instructions in the documentation, causing a panic.,
{code:java}
# openssl ecparam -genkey -name secp256k1 | openssl ec -out test.pem
read EC key
writing EC key
# seth account import test.pem test
Key at test.pem imported with alias test
# seth account create --wait test
panic: runtime error: invalid memory address or nil pointer dereference
[signal 0xb code=0x1 addr=0x0 pc=0x4aaacd]

goroutine 1 [running]:
panic(0x83eac0, 0xc8200100b0)
/usr/lib/go-1.6/src/runtime/panic.go:481 +0x3e6
sawtooth_seth/client.(*Client).LookupAccountNonce(0xc8203cbb10, 0xc8200b9e60, 0x20, 0x20, 0x20, 0x0, 0x0)
/build/sawtooth-seth/families/seth/src/sawtooth_seth/client/client.go:121 +0x35d
main.(*AccountCreate).Run(0xc82000a690, 0xc8203d6660, 0x0, 0x0)
/build/sawtooth-seth/families/seth/src/sawtooth_seth/cli/account_create.go:82 +0x369
main.(*Account).Run(0xc8200b93c0, 0xc8203d6660, 0x0, 0x0)
/build/sawtooth-seth/families/seth/src/sawtooth_seth/cli/account.go:60 +0x14e
main.main()
/build/sawtooth-seth/families/seth/src/sawtooth_seth/cli/main.go:102 +0xaa2
{code}

To show it works, here is an account created on the same Sawtooth network, successfully, using `--nonce=0` option:
{code}
# openssl ecparam -genkey -name secp256k1 | openssl ec -out brooklyn.pem
read EC key
writing EC key
# seth account import brooklyn.pem brooklyn
Key at brooklyn.pem imported with alias brooklyn
# seth account create --nonce=0 --wait brooklyn
Account created
Transaction Receipt:  {
  "TransactionID": "3c80176183b05659acc8b409f08b34f8d0371f5284ade4264eaf597f2453921e29dbfe7a826d8285408185aa96a36ba3725c7cfefd8becc51e52e9f3c9232163",
  "Address": "be1fc820344f85a4e50452c679f93b97a1388556"
}
{code}

This is accessing the running `seth-tp` container in a four validator network.

column1: PoET settings should be fully populated in state before starting poet consensus
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Currently poet has default values in the code. Those defaults can be overridden by changing settings in state.

This is an incomplete solution though, because if a new node is launched with different code with different defaults, there's no way for that node to get into agreement with the others.

Instead, all PoET settings should be added to state before poet can be started.

column1: Minimum wait time not attested to in the wait certficate
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: The minimum wait time is currently passed as a parameter to the creation of the wait timer. However, it is not included in any attestation. This would allow a validator to provide a bogus minimum wait time to timer creation that cannot be detected by other validators.
column146: 12/Jan/18 1:32 AM;cintel;Does the minimum wait time need to be configurable or can it be set as a constant in the enclave?;;;

column1: SGX timer nonce is not serialized in the wait timer
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: The timer nonce is used to ensure that no reset of the timer has occurred between two calls to get trusted time. The timer nonce is currently initialized during creation of the wait timer, but the value is thrown away and not used when checking the duration during wait certificate creation. This would allow for a potential attack based on re-initialization of the ME timer.

column1: reduce use of SGX monotonic counters
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: The current code reads and increments the monotonic counter every time a wait timer is created. This is overkill and can potentially lead to NVM wear out in the ME. The monotonic counter is required for protection over reboots, but an in-memory counter (that uses the monotonic counter as an epoch) should be sufficient.

column1: Reduce memory consumption on block catchup
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: When a validator is way behind on a long chain, the size of the chain it can catchup on is bounded by the available memory. See "Validator Catch-Up".
column146:
20/Feb/20 12:48 PM;jmbarry;We have run into this issue. This issue has been identified and pending since January, 2018. Our product is aimed at clients who have a a less than consistent connection across their enterprise, yet have the need for TPS in excess of 40. The result for high speed transaction systems who lose connectivity to a node for various reasons including network connections, issues with a VM, or physical machines issues etc. the node upon reconnection will attempt to load all missed transactions in order to catch up to the overall chain of validators. This flood of transactions is not limited by memory on the catch up validator, and will load all missing transactions until loaded or the machine runs out of memory.  If the number of transactions is too much for installed memory, you end up with an out of memory condition, as the number of transactions continue to go until available memory is gone.  With auto restart the validator node with continue to restart and try to load the transactions again and again.  Sawtooth needs to be able to have high speed systems that can bring a validator down and to come back gracefully in order to have the same ordered transactions as other nodes.    

The fix should be a CLI setting that the Sawtooth operator can set based on the total memory available for the validator node that needs to catch up to the transaction level off the chain.  This is a config that should be set when the validator is installed, based on the properties of the machine or VM that the validator node is working with.;;;
column147: 22/Feb/20 1:46 AM;jmbarry;For another reason that this is a high importance add on is in the adding nodes to an existing scenario.  We added a node to a system with 4.5 million entries in the blockchain.  The system 1.2 running PBFT, tried to add all 4.5 million transactions at once. The node crashed and auto-restarted and crashed again.  Nodes will be added in running systems.  These new nodes need to be able to add the existing transactions in an orderly way.;;;

column1: Node not receiving the genesis block from its peers
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
This edge case error occurs where a node's seeds also don’t have the genesis block, and therefore cannot respond to the the HEAD request that is initially made.  Since validators do not broadcast blocks received via a GossipBlockResponse, it will never receive the blocks from its peer even once those peers have received the block.
 
The suggested fix is that a node with an empty chain should re-request the HEAD block from it’s peers periodically until it has received one.

column146: 12/Jan/18 7:09 AM;rberg2;This looks like an issue with the sysadmin guide documentation. That file gets created by the command "poet genesis -k /etc/sawtooth/keys/validator.priv --enclave-module sgx -o poet_genesis.batch" If the command is run as a regular user it will fail because it can't read the private key, so running it as root is a natural thing to do. Instead the command should be run as the sawtooth user because that user can read the private key and write to /var/lib/sawtooth.;;;
column147: 13/Jan/18 2:07 AM;achenette;In this procedure, there is an earlier step that says "Become the sawtooth user and change to /tmp."  However, the procedure is confusing - it's easy to miss this step.  I'll make changes to reduce the confusion and make it easier to see which commands must be run as the sawtooth user.;;;
column148: 24/Jan/18 2:21 AM;achenette;I added a different prompt to the commands that must be run as the sawtooth user. See:  [Configure the Validator to Use SGX PoET|https://sawtooth.hyperledger.org/docs/core/nightly/master/sysadmin_guide/configure_sgx.html#configure-the-validator-to-use-sgx-poet].;;;

column1: Develop outline for Application Developer Guide rewrite
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.

column1: Improve database naming scheme
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Currently, the block store, global state, and transaction receipt databases all use the last two characters of the validator's network endpoint in their file names. The reason for doing this originally was to support multiple validators on the same machine but the network endpoint is not the right place to pull a unique identifier (it was used for historical reasons). Instead, multiple validators should be supported on the same machine by either:

1. Requiring separate data directories for different validators (configured using the path configuraiton)
2. Pulling a unique identifier from the validator's public key.

column1: Remove libpoet_bridge
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: The component libpoet_bridge is no longer necessary. it was initially introduced to provide an compiler runtime isolation on windows, since the python sdk and the sgx required different version of MSVC. Since we have moved to linux as the only supported platform. We can merge this component into the poet_enclave_sgx module.
column146:
13/Jan/18 8:33 AM;cintel;The code from libpoet_bridge can be added to the poet_enclave_sgx, all of the function in libpoet_bridge/poet.cpp can be merged into to their call sites with in the  poet_enclave_sgx nmodule. 
 * poet.cpp
 * signup_data.cpp
 * signup_info.cpp
 * wait_certificate.cpp
 * wait_timer.cpp

The goal is to remove the interface function entirely and place their logic at the call sites. In effect removing the libpoet_bridge so layer from the call stack. In addition. the (misplaced) header libpoet_shared/poet.h  should be renamed ( to poet_types.h) and only the data definitions needed to be shared between the poet_enclave_sgx and the enclave should remain in it. 

The other modules in libpoet_bridge
 * base64.cpp
base64.h
enclave.cpp
enclave.h
log.cpp
log.h
ocall.cpp
platform_support.h
sealed_data.cpp
sealed_data.h
utils.h

should be integrated into the poet_enclave_sgx directory and build. The windows/linux platform abstraction can safely be removed at this time also.

 ;;;

column1: Remove Base64.* from libpoet_bridge
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Convert the code in libpoet_bridge  to use the base64 libraries from openssl or libcryptopp.  Alternatively the structures can be returned as binary to python and can be converted to base64 there.

column1: Log full batch and transaction ids instead of truncating
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Example of a bad message that truncates the batch id:

Jan  9 11:11:13 ec2-184-72-66-148.compute-1.amazonaws.com [psimlr7-node7]    DEBUG                     Thread-54                        chain Invalid batch f6fae4cf encountered during verification of block 52bdda9387194b6e71e25a07bfe1a8f59154a07ef959dc1531ce7ecef4d81f031799d610b227c4c0b610e952a379b4ee2f37acd5a436be1b61abf0562b53a2f9 (block_num:55, state:5aee65406b9ac2f442fb710bbd58f9148489359f8378b90c6d670768828e5beb, previous_block_id:83de41121c8801ec4bfd5228ece9c9cb2ed0c63fb871aae721ad7554fe747121615f09a9ce2344701945bb47b4f541453d9fc38c9475b4194b43ffc89e708925)

column1: Block validation race condition on checking for transaction dependencies
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: There is a race condition when checking for transaction dependencies during block validation. The relevant class is the ChainCommitState, which depends on the block store. During operation of a test network, 9/10 nodes accepted a block as valid but 1 node marked it as invalid due to a missing transaction dependency.

column1: On networks with large chains, new nodes hang while catching up
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
Steps to reproduce:

1) Have a network with >= 4k blocks
2) Add a new node to the network

Expected:
Node catches up and processes as normal

Actual:
The node will begin catching up and stop processing blocks.

column1: Log reason for failed block validation
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32: Currently the block validator logs that a block failed, but it doesn't say why.

column1: Remove python sawadm implementation
column10: Hyperledger Sawtooth is a modular blockchain platform.
column32:
The python version of sawadm should be removed and the build scripts and tests updated to use the new rust version. The build scripts do not easily support installing packages from 2 languages in one docker container, making this difficult.

This branch is a start: https://github.com/aludvik/sawtooth-core/tree/sawadm-rust-replace-python
